## 1. Budget 2026 banks on stability while betting big on 7% growth

President Anura Kumara Dissanayakeâ€™s fourâ€‘hour Budget pitches fiscal discipline under the IMF programme and a mediumâ€‘term 7% growth target. Revenue is to rise to 15.3% of GDP and the deficit to narrow to about 5.2%, with digitalisation, trade facilitation and publicâ€“private partnerships (PPP) as growth levers. Business lobbies welcomed policy predictability and some longâ€‘sought fixes (trade single window, SOE reform laws, investor visas, 5G rollout). But they also warned the growth maths is thin without faster execution, a clearer investmentâ€‘incentive package and stronger tax administration. Critics called the 7% target optimistic, flagged a squeeze on SMEs from a lower VAT registration threshold (Rs. 36m) and queried whether capital spending is sufficient to lift productivity. The Budgetâ€™s political economy is now explicit: keep the IMF onside while trying to ease costâ€‘ofâ€‘living pain without derailing consolidation. ğŸ“Š

## 2. Devolution drifts as Provincial Councils remain in limbo

A chorus of actorsâ€”the Socialist Alliance, civil-society veterans and Tamil partiesâ€”demanded longâ€‘overdue Provincial Council (PC) elections. The Government cites delimitations as the blocker; opponents counter that Parliament (where the NPP holds twoâ€‘thirds) could legislate a return to the prior system as an interim step. ITAK (Tamil party) also objected to defenceâ€‘sector nominees for the Office of Reparations, arguing it would erode community trust in redress. The longer PCs stay under gubernatorial control, the more devolution looks mothballedâ€”a risk for governance at the periphery and for investor perceptions of predictability beyond Colombo. ğŸ—³ï¸

## 3. Governance claims face tests from markets to ministries

The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) hauled 150 directors into a plainâ€‘spoken clinic on liabilities and disclosure, underlining new beneficialâ€‘ownership deadlines and solvency tests. Elsewhere, antiâ€‘corruption headlines cut both ways: former Tourism Minister Prasanna Ranatunga was arrested and bailed over an alleged 2021 insuranceâ€‘broker deal; and the Opposition hammered the Government over a rushed tender for 1,775 doubleâ€‘cabs, alleging a 12â€‘day bid window and tailored specs. The administrationâ€™s promise of a cleaner state (and lower perks for officials) will be judged not by rhetoric but by audit trails, prosecutions and tenders that withstand scrutiny. ğŸ•µï¸

## 4. The digital state accelerates, but execution will be decisive

Five Indian firmsâ€”including Infosys and TCSâ€”were shortlisted to build Sri Lankaâ€™s MOSIPâ€‘based Unique Digital Identity (SLâ€‘UDI), with first cards slated for Q3 2026 and a local managedâ€‘services handover thereafter. INFOTEL 2025 showcased the $15bn digitalâ€‘economy ambition; Global Entrepreneurship Week launched under the rallying cry â€œTogether We Buildâ€; and a homeâ€‘grown secure dataâ€‘exchange platform (OnsysConnect) won national honours. The prize is bigâ€”faster services, cleaner registries and investor confidenceâ€”but so are the pitfalls: interâ€‘agency overlaps, cyber risk and delivery gaps that have stalled reforms before. ğŸ’»

## 5. Equities rally on Budget cheer as banks and deals take the lead

The Colombo bourse punched past 23,500, buoyed by Fitchâ€™s nod to fiscal consolidation, solid quarterly prints and budgetâ€‘friendly signals. DFCC agreed to acquire Standard Charteredâ€™s retail and wealth business; JF Packagingâ€™s IPO was 6.3x oversubscribed; and financials posted muscular results (LOLC Finance H1 PAT up 72% to Rs. 14bn; Seylanâ€™s net profit jumped on loan growth). Yet froth lurks: turnover is flattered by crossings and liquidity is still shallow. Sustaining the rally hinges on passing the PPP/SOE bills, deâ€‘risking debt service beyond 2028, and converting â€œpolicies on paperâ€ into shovelâ€‘ready pipelines. ğŸ“ˆ

## 6. Colombo courts capital while smoothing the diplomacy

The Budget recast Sri Lanka as â€œa friendly, honest destinationâ€ for investors, promising amendments to the Strategic Development Projects and Port City Acts, an Investment Protection Act and a streamlined landâ€‘allocation regime. Colombo Port Cityâ€™s regulator called it a potential â€œsingle catalystâ€ for growth, from fund management to arbitrationâ€”should visas, expat rules and IP processing be simplified. Abroad, Colombo deepened ties: it signed the Hajj 2026 agreement (3,500 quota), launched a Sri Lankaâ€“Saudi business council, invited Pope Leo XIV and secured UNESCOâ€™s annual Vesak day, amplifying soft power without costly concessions. ğŸŒ

## 7. Green shoots: biodiversity cash, cleaner waters and climateâ€‘smart pipes

Nature and water management made rare progress. The Kunming Biodiversity Fund approved FAOâ€‘led projects, including Sri Lankaâ€™s plan to tighten biosecurity and invasiveâ€‘species control. Cabinet backed four pilot pipelineâ€‘irrigation schemes (877 hectares) with JFPR/ADB support to curb drought losses and promote waterâ€‘efficient, higherâ€‘value crops; womenâ€™s participation is a stated goal. In Kandy, PM2.5 levels five times the WHO guideline spotlighted enforcement failures from buses to threeâ€‘wheelers; and MEPA with Dialog unveiled a 5Gâ€‘guided robot that skims floating wasteâ€”small tech, big symbolism. Indiaâ€“Sri Lanka legal scholars jointly mapped a crossâ€‘border environmental agenda for the Palk Bay and Gulf of Mannar. ğŸŒ¿

## 8. Tourism returns but talent is the constraint

Arrivals climbed, malls and events buzzed (One Galle Face marked six years with new brands; industry expos drew record crowds), yet the National Human Resource Development Council flagged a severe postâ€‘pandemic labour drain: 60% of hospitality resignations (2020â€“23) were for overseas jobs. Kitchen, F&B and housekeeping demand is outpacing supply, while women remain underâ€‘represented (24%) due to safety and care burdens. Fixing the skills pipelineâ€”modern curricula, apprenticeships, childcare and safer transportâ€”will matter more for 2026 revenues than destination slogans. ğŸ§³

## 9. The arithmetic of cars, credit and wages makes growth tricky

Vehicleâ€‘related lending gulped 63% of financeâ€‘company loans in H1 2025â€”Rs. 1.16tnâ€”boosting customs revenue but draining FX, pressuring the rupee and crowding out productive credit. A proposed daily wage lift for estate workers (toward Rs. 1,750) addresses hardship but will strain teaâ€‘sector margins unless tied to quality, replanting and brandingâ€”TRI marked its centenary warning about ageing bushes and low replanting rates. Meanwhile, Cabinet moved to fold two small housing lenders into BOC and Peopleâ€™s Bank to shore up capital adequacy. Without faster productivity gains, such patchâ€‘ups will not bend the growth curve. ğŸš—

## 10. Security and social cohesion get sharper edges

The Public Security Minister said seven Sri Lankan drug traffickers abroad had agreed to surrenderâ€”one sign that the antiâ€‘narcotics drive is reaching into foreign networks. Separately, the President alleged past State funds had bankrolled both Sinhala and Muslim extremistsâ€”a grave charge that, if investigated credibly, could reset how Sri Lanka treats violent politics. Hajj logistics, interfaith gestures (UNESCO Vesak, papal invitation) and highâ€‘level Saudi talks point to softâ€‘power calibration alongside hardâ€‘edged policing. âš–ï¸

## Model Prompt (for [gpt-5](https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-5))

```
You will be given several Sri Lankan news articles from the past week. Write a concise, cohesive editorial digest in the style of The Economist, but output it as a JSON list. Each list element must be a dict of the form:

{
  "title": "...",
  "body": "..."
}

Titles should be written as crisp, fully informative sentences. Follow each title with a short paragraph in "body" that adds context and nuance without bullets.

Go beyond summary and analyse how the weekâ€™s developments fit together. Use emojis purposefully, and explain any non-obvious acronyms or jargon. Stick strictly to verifiable facts.
```
